title: 105_hr1111
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lupus Research and Care Amendments of 1997". The Congress recognizes lupus as a serious autoimmune disease that predominantly affects women, with three main types: systemic lupus, discoid lupus, and drug-induced lupus. Lupus can be fatal if not detected early and can affect various parts of the body. It disproportionately affects African-American women. African-American women are three times more likely to develop lupus compared to white women. Between 1,400,000 and 2,000,000 Americans have been diagnosed with the disease. Current treatments can have damaging side effects, leading to debilitating pain and fatigue for many sufferers. In fiscal year 1996, the National Institutes of Health allocated $33,000,000 for lupus research, less than half a percent of their budget. Expansion and intensification of activities for lupus research under Title I of the Public Health Service Act. The Director of the Institute will expand and intensify research on lupus, coordinating with other national research institutes. Research will focus on understanding the causes and finding a cure for lupus, including investigating the higher prevalence in women, especially African-American women. Research on lupus will focus on understanding the causes and finding a cure, with a particular emphasis on the elevated prevalence in women, including African-American women. This includes basic research, epidemiological studies, improved screening techniques, clinical research for new treatments, and information and education programs. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998, with additional funding for 1999 and 2000. Establishment of program of grants for delivery of services regarding lupus. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants for projects to establish efficient systems for delivering essential services to individuals with lupus and their families. Grants can be given to public or nonprofit entities, including hospitals, community organizations, and health centers. Authorized activities include outpatient and ambulatory services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants for projects to establish efficient systems for delivering essential services to individuals with lupus and their families. This includes outpatient, ambulatory, and home-based health services, inpatient care management, improving healthcare quality and organization, and ensuring continuity of health insurance coverage. SEC. 202. CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS. A grant under section 201 requires the applicant to agree to specific conditions: using no more than 5% of the grant for administrative purposes, supplementing rather than replacing funds for lupus treatment, and not charging individuals below 200% of the poverty line for services. The applicant must adhere to specific conditions regarding charges based on income levels: not exceeding 5% for individuals below 200% of the poverty line, 7% for those between 200-300%, and 10% for those above 300%. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to help entities comply with the requirements of this title to be eligible for grants. Definitions include the "official poverty line" and the role of the Secretary of Health and Human Services. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998, with additional funding for subsequent years.
